articles.title: Electrons stop acting like particles—and physics still works
articles.description: Physicists have long relied on the idea that electrons behave like tiny particles zipping through materials, even though quantum physics says their exact position is fundamentally uncertain. Now, researchers at TU Wien have discovered something surprising: a material where this particle picture comp

articles.title: This after-meal blood sugar spike may raise Alzheimer’s risk
articles.description: Spikes in blood sugar after eating may be more dangerous for the brain than previously thought. In a massive genetic study, people with higher post-meal blood sugar had a much greater risk of Alzheimer’s disease. The effect couldn’t be explained by visible brain damage, suggesting hidden biological

articles.title: Scientists question the safety of BPA-free packaging
articles.description: “BPA-free” food packaging may be hiding new risks. A McGill University study found that several BPA substitutes used in grocery price labels can seep into food and interfere with vital processes in human ovarian cells. Some triggered unusual fat buildup and disrupted genes linked to cell repair and

articles.title: Forest loss is driving mosquitoes’ thirst for human blood
articles.description: In the rapidly disappearing Atlantic Forest, mosquitoes are adapting to a human-dominated landscape. Scientists found that many species now prefer feeding on people rather than the forest’s diverse wildlife. This behavior dramatically raises the risk of spreading dangerous viruses such as dengue and

articles.title: Northwestern Medicine’s new antibody wakes the immune system against pancreatic cancer
articles.description: Pancreatic cancer uses a sugar-coated disguise to evade the immune system, helping explain why it’s so hard to treat. articles.title: HILL and THOMPSON: Bearspaw feeder break underscores troubling governance issues at city hall
articles.description: The panel doesn’t point to one cartoon villain who sabotaged Calgary’s water system. Rather, it shows how — for at least two decades — city officials and politicians lacked clear incentives to prioritize maintenance and backup capacity for Calgary’s water utility.
